caption: This is the municipal museum of the city of Versailles. There are three different levels with different collections on each. This is a great option to see some beautiful French artifacts without fighting the crowds at the chateau. Entry was cheap, I believe 5 Euro.

I love these little museums off the beaten track. Small and quiet but still interesting. Lovely collection of paintings and objects. Peronally I loved the period rooms. It gives you a good idea of what these houses looked like in the past as most of the wood panelling is still in tact. Definitely recommended when in Versailles.

A well-presented little museum which is an alternative (or accompaniment) to the palace. Has a variety of exhibits and takes you through the history of the town. The main text in each room is also presented in English - which is handy as I don't understand much (any) French!

Not very well known museum in Versailles ville. An eclectic art and furniture family collection which befits the era. Very well documented events for the French Revolution and a portrait of Miss Charlotte Corday who murdered Marat for the right reasons. Coupled with a visit to the Mus√©e Picasso in Paris, good to see the portrait of this unusual killer. Then the events which saw Napoleon‚Äôs rise etc are also very well documented. Building itself is in need of further care as a strange scent emanates from the wooden structure but a really great place to visit to understand French history and the history of Versailles.
A gem of a place. Quaint little 18th century chateau where you can learn a lot about Versailles!

Nice small museum.  The signage is only in French so if you do not read the language plan to just enjoy the paintings and items for their beauty and historical interest.  Enjoyable apartment setup as it looked in the 17th century.  Friendly staff.  Three floors with creaky stairs.  Well worth the 5 ‚Ç¨ entrance charge.  We spent about one hour at the museum.

So glad I skipped the gardens at Versailles to see this lovely museum. It's bigger than it looks and will transport you back in time to 18th century France. I loved the authentically squeaky hardwood floors. Practical info- No English translations. Give yourself an hour.
I had a wonderful experience here in the perfume store where you get to drink matching tea with your fragrance. I loved it. It was quite late to go there I guess as other stores had closed.
Excellent little museum  Very well curated
A well-presented little museum which is an alternative
This is the municipal museum of the city of Versailles.
Beautiful xviii s and exhibition s

Magnificent museum far from the hustle and bustle of the castle, both for the place itself, charming and authentic, and for the quality of the collections on display.  I really liked the living room with the harp and the ceramics, the 19th/20th paintings including a magnificent Le Sidaner and a nice little surprise with this miniature ivory jewel by Vig√©e le Brun, from a painting that I don't have failed to see the castle on the day of my visit üòÇ

We discovered this small museum by chance and we were delighted: well documented, well arranged, the museum immerses us in the history of Versailles before and after the Revolution and offers beautiful collections of paintings, sculptures and decorative objects. Not to be missed!

Charming and pleasant museum in the center of Versailles. Paintings, sculptures, furniture and refined living rooms with interesting explanations. Allow 1h30 to visit it. Free the last Sundays of each month. Sunday market 2 steps from the museum. A great time guaranteed üëç‚öúÔ∏èüòä

Good complement after visiting the castle. Numerous paintings and sculptures mixing the eras. The welcome is friendly. Parking is quite easy on the main boulevard which adjoins the museum, Boulevard de la Reine. For people with reduced mobility, an elevator provides access to the upper floors.
Museum to see if you spend a few days in Versailles, beautiful house filled with works of art and recounting the history of France century after century.

A museum rich and diverse in its collection, displayed on several levels. It is, however, a shame that we cannot approach closer to certain rooms, which are quite far from the visitor. In addition, the welcome was a little cold and the presence of the security guard who followed me into each room I went to on the ground floor, as if I were planning to steal a chest of drawers, was quite annoying. Fortunately, the ladies on the floors greet visitors with a hello and guide them through the rooms.

Great private mansion. In each room the content is well explained, very spacious, the natural light allows the objects to be highlighted, the lighting when necessary does not harm the works on display

A small house of art and history with a very pleasant calm and intimate atmosphere. A true immersion in the past of Versailles, with a collection of paintings, sculptures and furniture. Free every 1st Sunday of the month.

I really like it. It feels private. and get a good feeling Starting with the lovely, attentive staff. Whatever questions you ask, they answer enthusiastically. It is a very suitable place for playing.

This beautiful mansion on Boulevard de la Reine houses the museum, which could be called the Versailles City Museum, because it is here that collections relating to Versailles have been brought together.  On three floors you will find impressive antiques and works by Versailles artists, busts, antique furniture, entire rooms and decorative objects, from the sophisticated to the massive from the Ancien R√©gime through the Revolution to the 20th century.  I recommend the combination ticket together with the Espace Richaud. We took our time and spent two wonderful hours in the exhibition. I think the city villa itself is an attraction.
A beautiful mansion belonging to the Lambinet family. Pictures by Versailles artists from the Revolution to the 18th century. Likewise furniture and busts.

Visit this ‚Äúsmall‚Äù museum in Versailles. Ultra discreet. A carriage entrance, a small garden with deck chairs for a reading break. That's the framework. Afterwards we enter a three-story residence retracing the history of France through Versailles. History through paintings but also ‚Äúeveryday‚Äù objects. The place belonged to an art collector. To do without hurry

In Versailles, I only knew the famous castle of the Sun King which I have already visited twice in the past. I wanted to learn more about this ancient royal city.  With my friend, we visited this superb little mansion which houses the collections of the Lambinet museum. On the first floor, a succession of rooms decorated and furnished in the style of the 18th century allows you to discover and admire a beautiful diversity of paintings, sculptures and other objects of art. The second floor is an opportunity to delve in a fascinating way into the History of Versailles under the Ancien R√©gime, during the French Revolution and in the 19th Century. I really liked this little museum which deserves to be better known.

Magnificent private hotel with an intimate and calm side which really contrasts with the crowds at the nearby Chateau.  Very beautiful restitution of the atmosphere of the art of living of a wealthy family in Versailles in the 18th century.  With its different floors you will find numerous objects, paintings, and rooms which span the history of Versailles from the ancient regime to the revolution and more.  A visit to make alone or with family, in this museum on a human scale with such a pleasant atmosphere.

The place is nice to visit. The building is pretty and renovated. The museum has a history that must be discovered and the exhibitions are interesting. There are paintings and sculptures dating from the time of the Ancien R√©gime and the French Revolution... 6‚Ç¨ per place is quite reasonable but I recommend going there on the last Sundays of the month or on heritage days, days during which the museum is free.

A very pleasant museum with its share of paintings, sculptures, decorations, mainly 18th century but not only... a plus: free on the last Sunday of the month. I recommend it as part of a visit to the city and the nearby antiques district.

In Versailles, I visited this place after being introduced by my daughter. Although the room is not large, the collection is quite rich and has a sense of the times. The portraits, sculptures, and furniture items all have history, and the exhibits are decorated with a sense of life. It is said that they are all exquisite pieces collected by celebrities. Friends who like characters and details of life can experience itüë®‚Äçüë®‚Äçüëß‚Äçüë¶

Magnificent museum... I had spotted this museum for a long time and I finally visited it this weekend... This museum is full of magnificent objects from several collections... Very beautiful furniture is presented... Museum has do without a doubt...

Museum recently reopened after works. The Lambinet museum bears the name of this family sensitive to art and attached to the city of Versailles. The last occupant offered this 18th century mansion to the city of Versailles. A very pleasant journey through time. Paintings, sculptures, earthenware, furniture are very well presented. To do.
A charming museum that deserves to be better known with absolutely sumptuous art collections. It‚Äôs a very friendly and refreshing place!
Small museum of heterogeneous works. Clear and careful presentation. Pleasant setting of a small private hotel. Entrance on Boulevard de la Reine.
Very interesting this museum on the history of Versailles and the Ch√¢teau de Versailles in an old historic building!!!! Enjoy free entry last Sunday of the month!!!

Visit and discover this pretty museum during a sensory tasting event held regularly. An opportunity to combine visual and gustatory pleasures. The recently renovated place exhibits lovely collections. To do and see

Beautiful private mansion filled with various objects relating to the daily life of noble or bourgeois families living in Versailles, at different times. Everything is decorated with paintings and sculptures by various artists, with an interesting point about the French Revolution.
Magnificent little museum! Eclectic collections in a neat and very well restored setting. Currently, the exhibition on Antonio de La Gandara is lovely.
Very nice little museum on the history of France but more specifically during the period from Louis XIV to the end of the monarchy
